name: methyl_butyl_ether
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: 1,3-dioxolane has a melting point of -106.0 degrees Celsius. The basic unit for comparison is ethanol, which has a melting point of -114.1 degrees Celsius. The methyl group introduces a rigid structure, which can participate in hydrogen bonding, raising the melting point by approximately +5 degrees Celsius. The methyl group also introduces a bulky side chain, which can increase the melting point due to steric hindrance and molecular volume, estimated at around +5 degrees Celsius. The butyl group introduces additional rigidity and molecular weight, estimated at around +10 degrees Celsius. The dioxane-like bridging moiety also contributes to the melting point, estimated at around +5 degrees Celsius.
